pr_title: Add returning clause to update-by-id usecase to the storage engine

timeline.bodyText:
AnalyzedRelation and AnalyzedUpdateStatement and also later AnalyzedInsertStatement could share an interface marking these 3 classes that they have outputfields to simplify the code here. Something like
interface OutputFieldStatement { Fields fields(); }
timeline.author: mkleen

replies.bodyText: Sounds reasonable, I think ResultSetStatement  describes the iface better (maybe we can come up with an even better name?).
replies.author: seut

timeline.bodyText: The serialization can be optimized here, since the types of the rows are already known. Also the version needs to taking into account for backward compatibility.
timeline.author: mkleen

timeline.bodyText: ShardUpsertRequest contains already the information for a lot of use cases. It would make sense to split this eventually up as @mfussenegger already suggested.
timeline.author: mkleen

replies.bodyText: I would probably tackle this later.
replies.author: mkleen

timeline.bodyText: Would it make sense to split this class into 2 separate executors one for counting, one to retrieve return values ? Or maybe expose the possibility to handle ActionListener to the caller and leave the way the return values are handled to the outside of this class ?
timeline.author: mkleen

replies.bodyText: Another option would be to leave conversion helper methods here (they can be all static afaik) and built the MultiActionListener at the caller (or using static methods which may stay here). I think most of the stuff here is already very generic so splitting this up into 2 implementations just for wrangling the results sounds a bit too much to me.
replies.author: seut

replies.bodyText: Would the current state be sufficient ?
replies.author: mkleen

timeline.bodyText: Multiple rows may returned here.
timeline.author: seut

replies.bodyText: Yes, good point, this is not correct. This is the wrong type here. My guess is that the result type should be List<Row> and not a Row, there is also a deduplication step missing I assume. I will come back to this.
replies.author: mkleen

timeline.author: seut

timeline.bodyText: Looks like an Object[] could be used directly as the length is known
timeline.author: seut

timeline.message: Introduce ResultSetStatement to mark Statements with Resultsets
Make systemcolumns available as return values

timeline.author: mfussenegger

timeline.bodyText:
This could probably go into the constructor? Maybe even change the dependencies to List<Field> ("don't be greedy"). Maybe also add a short javadoc explaining that fields/returnValues are for the RETURNING clause.
Also: What's the difference between the returnValues and the fields? Both are symbols.
timeline.author: mfussenegger

timeline.bodyText:
I think this should not be nullable. This seems to be the case only because in the UPDATE case RETURNING is optional. Which makes me wonder if having a separate interface/doing instance of checks on it is the right approach.
Maybe AnalyzedStatement generally has nullable fields?
timeline.author: mfussenegger

+
+public interface ResultSetStatement extends AnalyzedStatement {
+
+    @Nullable

timeline.bodyText: Maybe we could be a bit more verbose here. values is a bit generic and doesn't contain any information about the format and what kind of values. Are these the columns, or the rows?
timeline.author: mfussenegger

timeline.bodyText: Could we use the existing InputFactory.ctxForRefs .. stuff instead? Seems like a slightly different variant to accomplish the same as we generally use the inputs for.
timeline.author: mfussenegger

timeline.bodyText: Could some of the tests be converted to unit tests, or do all of these have to be on a integration test level?
timeline.author: mfussenegger

timeline.message: Add versioning for BwC to ShardRequest/Response

timeline.bodyText:
I still don't feel good about the Nullable here + ResultSetStatement solution.
The interface doesn't mark fields() as Nullable, so whoever uses a resultSetStatement might assume that it is not-null, but then we've specific implementations like this where fields is nullable.
This is rather trappy imho and a NPE waiting to happen.
In https://github.com/crate/crate/pull/9481/files#diff-8df7e31e8934a6bebea6f7bf4532b50cR596-R599 it is taking care of it, but still.
How about we move fields() to AnalyzedStatement, make it Nullable and get rid of the ResultSetStatement  interface? If the fields are there, it is a statement with result set, if it is not there, it isn't.
timeline.author: mfussenegger

timeline.bodyText:
Usually we build the fields inside the statements constructor, and the relation that they point to is this. See for example the QueriedSelectRelation.
I think we should also do that in the update case, as it makes it harder to build a "invalid" AnalyzedUpdateStatement instance.
timeline.author: mfussenegger

timeline.bodyText:
Would it make sense to keep these only in local scope and derive them from the resultColumns as needed? Would make the relation-ship between resultColumns and resultRowStreamers clearer (that one is derived from the other)
There is also a Symbols.streamerArray function which can be used to do so.
timeline.author: mfussenegger

     private List<Failure> failures = new ArrayList<>();
+

+     * Result rows are used to return values from updated rows.
+     */

+
+    /**
+     * Result columns describe the types of the result rows.
+     */
+    @Nullable
+    private Symbol[] resultColumns;
+
+    /**
+     * Streamers to stream return values from updated rows.
+     */
+    @Nullable
+    private Streamer[] resultRowStreamers;
